nodes.title: IMPORTNANT
widgets_values:
This flow is needs a lot of VRAM (tested on 5070ti 16GB and is fine).  As such, please dont set the height in the ImageResInfo node to anything higher than 1440p unless you have a 4090/5090.  

If you want it larger OR longer, consider taking the video generated from the first Video Combine output and run that video through the "Video to SBS Video" workflow above.

nodes.title: CLIP Text Encode (Positive Prompt)
widgets_values: Buss lightyear is standing looking at you, the bear in the background walks over to buzz and gives him a hug

ARRGGHH ! What do all the settings do!     **********  SkyboxVR needs "_FULL_SBS" somewhere in the filename *******************
****************************************

Here's some help:

As all humans and all images are different, you will have to work out a setting that is best for you. If you know VR then you will understand we dont have the same IPD and depending on what you want to 'pop' out of the image is subjective. Use the text_debug output to connect to the filename, so you know what settings you used on that image, so can make adjustments based on your preference.


ipd_norm is a scalar multiplier that represents how far apart the virtual cameras (left & right) are, relative to the image width. It does not mean real-world millimeters. It simulates the effect of changing the interpupillary distance (IPD) in a normalized coordinate system so it works across different image resolutions.Humans average ~63mm IPD—but we can't use actual mm, because the image isn’t in mm.

ipd_norm gives a relative virtual baseline like:
ipd_norm	Real-world analogy
0.01–0.03	macro photography, tiny baseline
0.04–0.07	normal human eye spacing-ish
0.08–0.12	exaggerated 3D, hyper stereo
0.15+	toy stereo, uncomfortable, breaks depth cues


depth_strength affects how much depth varies disparity.ipd_norm affects how much all disparity is scaled globally
In simple terms:
depth_strength controls how strong foreground vs background separation is.  ipd_norm controls how wide the stereo baseline is overall.



max_disp_norm sets the maximum allowed horizontal shift (disparity) between the left and right eye projections, expressed as a fraction of image width.  It acts as a safety clamp so that depth-based parallax doesn’t become extreme or uncomfortable
0.00–0.02	Almost no 3D
0.03–0.06	Natural stereo depth
0.07–0.12	Strong pop-out effects
>0.15	        Exaggerated / fake depth


focus_mode decides which depth value is treated as the "screen plane", meaning the depth level where there is zero stereo disparity (no left/right shift). Everything closer than that pops toward the viewer, everything farther sinks into the frame. It basically defines what part of the scene feels “at screen distance” rather than floating outward or inward.

focus_mode = "median" (automatic / default)
This calculates the median depth across the scene: focus = median(depth_map)
Meaning: Whatever depth most of the image sits at becomes the stable plane. Foreground objects pop out. Background sinks slightly. This works best when: Subject is centered, Depth map is clean, Scene isn't ultra-wide, Good default for portraits and normal indoor scenes.

focus_mode = "manual" (complete control)
Here you pick the plane using:  manual_focus (0.0 = far, 1.0 = near)
So if you want the subject to sit on the screen plane (no stereo shift): Set manual_focus to that subject’s depth.
If you want to push the whole scene back (3D theatrics):Use a far depth like 0.2.
If you want things to pop out aggressively: Use a deeper background focus and let subject be closer than focus

How to choose values
Goal	Mode	manual_focus suggestion
Natural portrait	median	N/A
Subject on the screen plane	manual	~0.6–0.75
Background on screen plane	manual	~0.2–0.3
Maximum pop-out	manual	~0.1
Make everything flat	manual	≈ depth of the whole scene


The node can take a depth map externally such as Depth Anything (which is better) but the node also has a depthmap within it, it is not as good as Depth Anything but it can offer subtlety of 3D


**********  SkyboxVR needs "_FULL_SBS" somewhere in the filename *******************

nodes.title: PRESETS
widgets_values:
Presets:  If you select Default then you can overide the seetings with the sliders, If you select anything other than default then those settings are predeined.


DEFAULT (Manual Mode)
Uses whatever your UI sliders are set to, nothing overridden.

STRONG_POP | Effect | Very strong pop-out foreground, mild background |
ipd_norm = 0.12
depth_strength = 1.4
max_disp_norm = 0.12
fg_boost = 1.8
bg_boost = 0.9
focus_mode = "Median"

CINEMATIC | Effect | Natural depth, low strain |
ipd_norm = 0.05
depth_strength = 0.9
max_disp_norm = 0.06
fg_boost = 1.1
bg_boost = 1.1
focus_mode = "Median"

BACKGROUND_DEPTH | Effect | Foreground mostly flat, background has deep parallax |
ipd_norm = 0.06
depth_strength = 1.0
max_disp_norm = 0.10
fg_boost = 0.2
bg_boost = 2.2
focus_mode = "Median"

PORTRAIT | Effect | Minimal facial warping, depth behind the subject |
ipd_norm = 0.04
depth_strength = 0.7
max_disp_norm = 0.05
fg_boost = 0.9
bg_boost = 1.2
focus_mode = "Manual"
manual_focus = 0.70
 
FOCUS_LOCK (manual focal plane) | Effect | Strong pop-out only for objects near chosen plane |
ipd_norm = 0.06
depth_strength = 1.0
max_disp_norm = 0.10
fg_boost = 2.0
bg_boost = 1.0
focus_mode = "Manual"
manual_focus = 0.35

REVERSE_PARALLAX | Effect | Depth inverted—everything goes into the screen |
max_disp_norm = 0.10
fg_boost = 0.8
bg_boost = 1.6
invert_internal_depth = True
invert_external_depth = False

VR180_PREP (for equirect projection node afterwards) | Effect | Wide stereo suitable for hemisphere projection |
ipd_norm = 0.09
depth_strength = 1.3
max_disp_norm = 0.15
focus_mode = "Manual"
manual_focus = 0.55
invert_internal_depth = False

nodes.title: CLIP Text Encode (Positive Prompt)
widgets_values: A close-up of buzz lightyear standing on a wooden floor, behind him is an evil big teddy bear looming over buzz's head. The teddy bears fist is clenched and is about to punch buzz with his paw, the tedy bear has an evil expression, various childrens toys scattered across the floor, Set in a kids bedroom, 3D pixar style

nodes.title: Show Any (Debug Settings - use this in the file name so you know what settings you used
Image Concatenate (this merges left/right eye images) ** You may need to swap them based on your headset**
Image Concatenate (this merges left/right eye images) ** You may need to swap them based on your headset**
Preview Image (the more you see the more it will 'pop')

widgets_values: The more you see, potentially the greater the effect

****************************************

Here's some help:

As all humans and all images are different, you will have to work out a setting that is best for you. If you know VR then you will understand we dont have the same IPD and depending on what you want to 'pop' out of the image is subjective. Use the text_debug output to connect to the filename, so you know what settings you used on that image, so can make adjustments based on your preference.

It simulates the effect of changing the interpupillary distance (IPD) in a normalized coordinate system so it works across different image resolutions.Humans average ~63mm IPD—but we can't use actual mm, because the image isn’t in mm.

ipd_norm gives a relative virtual baseline like:

0.01–0.03	macro photography, tiny baseline
0.04–0.07	normal human eye spacing-ish
0.08–0.12	exaggerated 3D, hyper stereo
0.15+	toy stereo, uncomfortable, breaks depth cues

depth_strength affects how much depth varies disparity.ipd_norm affects how much all disparity is scaled globally
In simple terms:
depth_strength controls how strong foreground vs background separation is.  ipd_norm controls how wide the stereo baseline is overall.

max_disp_norm sets the maximum allowed horizontal shift (disparity) between the left and right eye projections, expressed as a fraction of image width.  It acts as a safety clamp so that depth-based parallax doesn’t become extreme or uncomfortable
0.00–0.02	Almost no 3D
0.03–0.06	Natural stereo depth
0.07–0.12	Strong pop-out effects
>0.15	        Exaggerated / fake depth

focus_mode decides which depth value is treated as the "screen plane", meaning the depth level where there is zero stereo disparity (no left/right shift). Everything closer than that pops toward the viewer, everything farther sinks into the frame. It basically defines what part of the scene feels “at screen distance” rather than floating outward or inward.

focus_mode = "median" (automatic / default)
This calculates the median depth across the scene: focus = median(depth_map)
Meaning: Whatever depth most of the image sits at becomes the stable plane. Foreground objects pop out. Background sinks slightly. This works best when: Subject is centered, Depth map is clean, Scene isn't ultra-wide, Good default for portraits and normal indoor scenes.

Here you pick the plane using:  manual_focus (0.0 = far, 1.0 = near)

If you want to push the whole scene back (3D theatrics):Use a far depth like 0.2.
If you want things to pop out aggressively: Use a deeper background focus and let subject be closer than focus

How to choose values
Goal	Mode	manual_focus suggestion
Natural portrait	median	N/A
Subject on the screen plane	manual	~0.6–0.75
Background on screen plane	manual	~0.2–0.3
Maximum pop-out	manual	~0.1
Make everything flat	manual	≈ depth of the whole scene

The node can take a depth map externally such as Depth Anything (which is better) but the node also has a depthmap within it, it is not as good as Depth Anything but it can offer subtlety of 3D

**********  SkyboxVR needs "_FULL_SBS" somewhere in the filename *******************
If you are running a realy long video via this workflow or another worflow, whats on the right is how you would conect it, starting from VHS Path Cleaner node

nodes.title: *** ***     What is Pulfrich Effect   ***  ***
widgets_values:
This isnt your typical 3D, but its here because its another option for 3D purists.

If you were to upload video to Youtube, where the left and right image are identical and meta tag it, the two images would be merge and you would just see a normal video, no 3d effect at all, as they are identical images ans arent offset like a normal SBS.

But if you make the video with the Pulfrich Effect it basically draws the right side 1 frame behind the left side. So if you then put a sunglass lens (just an average pair, not too dark) over your right eye and keep both eyes open, the video will appear as 3D, because the right side is dark and 1 frame behind, it causes your brain to process the optics with a slight delay like a lag, that suddenly what you see is in 3D.

** It is important to emphaise this only works where the video is in motion right to the left or objects are moving from the right to the left.  You can of course use a video where the motion is left to right, but then you would have to output the video (swap_eyes=true) and put the lens over your left eye.

The effect only works on the horizontal axis, doing a top to bottom motion will do nothing

nodes.title: IMPORTNANT
widgets_values:
*****IMPORTAMT*****
The VHS Suite Meta Batch Manager node is broken as of 24th Nov 2025. If you get an message "ValueError: too many values to unpack (expected 5)" then do the below:

If updating doesnt fix the issue, inside my comfyui-latent-sbs\workflow example folder there is a utils.zip file.  Unzip the utils.py file and over write the one in comfyui-videohelpersuite\videohelpersuite folder. This will fix the VHS Meta Batch Manager node.

nodes.title: VFRAM HUNGRY
widgets_values:
Video to Video is VRAM hungy which is why we do it in batches, as the images for SBS are high resolution

If you run out of vram, consider decreasing the frames per batch. 

ALWAYS make sure that the last batch run is 2 frames or greater. eg. 81 frames total, dont do 20 frames per batch, as that means the last frame will be just 1 frame in a batch run

nodes.title: About the Ease Node
widgets_values:
VFI Ease In / Ease Out is a helper node designed to smooth the start and/or end of an image sequence/Video using GIMM VFI, while keeping the middle of the sequence largely unchanged.

Its purpose is to prevent harsh or sudden motion at the beginning or end of a clip — for example:   A camera move that starts too abruptly, A clip that ends too suddenly without easing out, or even setting VHS Combine PinPong mode on, which cause an abrupt reversal, this node will smooth the transition in and out.


Instead of interpolating the entire sequence evenly, this node:
Densifies frames only at the start and/or end and optionally applies a global VFI pass
It is designed specifically to work with GIMM-VFI (which is better than RIFE)

What the Node Does:
Internally, the node follows this process: Split → Ease Ends (VFI) → Recombine → Global VFI → FPS Retime
The first N frames = start section
The last N frames = end section

How does it recombine
The eased ends are stitched back together with the untouched middle and duplicate frames at boundaries are automatically avoided, finally it converts the interpolated sequence to a clean target FPS

Settings:
Ease Frames: Default: 6
Number of frames at the start and/or end that will be eased.
0 = no easing
Max Value is clamped so it can never exceed half the clip length
These frames are the only ones affected by the "Start /end VFI passes x2)

Ease Mode:
Start only – ease in, sharp end
Both ends – smooth start and finish
End only – sharp start, ease out

Source FPS: Default: 16
This is used for correct timing calculations.

Target FPS:Default: 30
Final output FPS after all interpolation and retiming.

Start / End VFI Passes (×2):Default: 1
How many VFI passes to apply only to the eased frames.
Each pass doubles the frame count:
1 = ×2
2 = ×4
3 = ×8
0 = disable easing interpolation
This affects only the start/end sections, not the middle.


Global VFI Passes (×2):Default: 1
Applies VFI to the entire recombined sequence.
Each pass doubles the full sequence:
0 = no global smoothing
1 = ×2
2 = ×4
Useful for overall motion smoothness after easing.


FPS Resample
Options:
Even Drop
Distributes dropped frames evenly over time (best for smooth motion)
Nearest
Uses nearest-frame sampling (sharper but can stutter slightly)


***Please do not change these settings:!!***
VFI Node Select:Default 'Auto'
Currently auto-detects the best available GIMM-VFI interpolate node.
vfi_node_key_override: Default: GIMMVFI_interpolate
VFI Model Loader Key Override: Default: DownloadAndLoadGIMMVFIModel

nodes.title: About the Bullet Time Node
widgets_values:
In the nodes folder under VideoExamples folder there is a HighJump video to demo a subtle bullet time

Use the following in that example
source 25fps
Target 25fps
SlowStart 99
SlowEnd 121
Ramp 9
RampVFI 2
Plateau 2

*ALWAYS make sure the gap(difference) between Slow Start/End frames is at least twice the ramp frames.

Similiar to the Ease/Out, but takes the runs the video normal until it gets to the Slow_start_frame
There it then starts to slow down the video over a number of frames (ramp_frames). Once these frames have process, it then slows down the video at runs at a slow constant rate as set in the plateau settings
The whe it hits the frame number in Slow_end_frame, it ramps back up to normal speed.

Whilst not perfect, it mimics a bullet time effect (as in timing and speed)


When the flow hits this node, it will look like its running multiple times, with a minimum of 5 passes
1 is for the Start
2 if for the ramp down
3 is for the plateau
4 is for the ramp up
5 is for the end

Any additional passes is depenand on how much you slow it down in the vfi_settings

widgets_values:
Presets:  If you select Default then you can overide the seetings with the sliders, If you select anything other than default then those settings are predeined.


DEFAULT (Manual Mode)
Uses whatever your UI sliders are set to, nothing overridden.

STRONG_POP | Effect | Very strong pop-out foreground, mild background |
ipd_norm = 0.12
depth_strength = 1.4
max_disp_norm = 0.12
fg_boost = 1.8
bg_boost = 0.9
focus_mode = "Median"

CINEMATIC | Effect | Natural depth, low strain |

bg_boost = 2.2
focus_mode = "Median"

PORTRAIT | Effect | Minimal facial warping, depth behind the subject |

depth_strength = 0.7
max_disp_norm = 0.05
fg_boost = 0.9
bg_boost = 1.2
focus_mode = "Manual"
manual_focus = 0.70
 


**** My preferemce as best balance ****
FOCUS_LOCK (manual focal plane) | Effect | Strong pop-out only for objects near chosen plane |
ipd_norm = 0.06
depth_strength = 1.0
max_disp_norm = 0.10
fg_boost = 2.0
bg_boost = 1.0
focus_mode = "Manual"
manual_focus = 0.35
**** My preferemce as best balance ****




REVERSE_PARALLAX | Effect | Depth inverted—everything goes into the screen |
max_disp_norm = 0.10
fg_boost = 0.8
bg_boost = 1.6
invert_internal_depth = True
invert_external_depth = False

VR180_PREP (for equirect projection node afterwards) | Effect | Wide stereo suitable for hemisphere projection |
ipd_norm = 0.09
depth_strength = 1.3
max_disp_norm = 0.15
focus_mode = "Manual"
manual_focus = 0.55
invert_internal_depth = False

ARRGGHH ! What do all the settings do!   **********  SkyboxVR needs "_FULL_SBS" somewhere in the filename *******************
****************************************

Here's some help:

As all humans and all images are different, you will have to work out a setting that is best for you. If you know VR then you will understand we dont have the same IPD and depending on what you want to 'pop' out of the image is subjective. Use the text_debug output to connect to the filename, so you know what settings you used on that image, so can make adjustments based on your preference.

ipd_norm is a scalar multiplier that represents how far apart the virtual cameras (left & right) are, relative to the image width. It does not mean real-world millimeters. It simulates the effect of changing the interpupillary distance (IPD) in a normalized coordinate system so it works across different image resolutions.Humans average ~63mm IPD—but we can't use actual mm, because the image isn’t in mm.

ipd_norm gives a relative virtual baseline like:
ipd_norm	Real-world analogy
0.01–0.03	macro photography, tiny baseline
0.04–0.07	normal human eye spacing-ish
0.08–0.12	exaggerated 3D, hyper stereo
0.15+	toy stereo, uncomfortable, breaks depth cues

depth_strength affects how much depth varies disparity.ipd_norm affects how much all disparity is scaled globally
In simple terms:
depth_strength controls how strong foreground vs background separation is.  ipd_norm controls how wide the stereo baseline is overall.

max_disp_norm sets the maximum allowed horizontal shift (disparity) between the left and right eye projections, expressed as a fraction of image width.  It acts as a safety clamp so that depth-based parallax doesn’t become extreme or uncomfortable
0.00–0.02	Almost no 3D
0.03–0.06	Natural stereo depth
0.07–0.12	Strong pop-out effects
>0.15	        Exaggerated / fake depth

focus_mode decides which depth value is treated as the "screen plane", meaning the depth level where there is zero stereo disparity (no left/right shift). Everything closer than that pops toward the viewer, everything farther sinks into the frame. It basically defines what part of the scene feels “at screen distance” rather than floating outward or inward.

focus_mode = "median" (automatic / default)
This calculates the median depth across the scene: focus = median(depth_map)
Meaning: Whatever depth most of the image sits at becomes the stable plane. Foreground objects pop out. Background sinks slightly. This works best when: Subject is centered, Depth map is clean, Scene isn't ultra-wide, Good default for portraits and normal indoor scenes.

focus_mode = "manual" (complete control)
Here you pick the plane using:  manual_focus (0.0 = far, 1.0 = near)
So if you want the subject to sit on the screen plane (no stereo shift): Set manual_focus to that subject’s depth.
If you want to push the whole scene back (3D theatrics):Use a far depth like 0.2.
If you want things to pop out aggressively: Use a deeper background focus and let subject be closer than focus

How to choose values
Goal	Mode	manual_focus suggestion
Natural portrait	median	N/A
Subject on the screen plane	manual	~0.6–0.75
Background on screen plane	manual	~0.2–0.3
Maximum pop-out	manual	~0.1
Make everything flat	manual	≈ depth of the whole scene

The node can take a depth map externally such as Depth Anything (which is better) but the node also has a depthmap within it, it is not as good as Depth Anything but it can offer subtlety of 3D

**********  SkyboxVR needs "_FULL_SBS" somewhere in the filename *******************

Strength
What it is:
Overall intensity multiplier for the depth effect.
What happens when you increase it:
Background appears to sit further back
Foreground feels slightly closer
The “pull apart in Z” feeling becomes more noticeable
What happens when you decrease it:
Depth effect fades
Image approaches the original flat look
👉 If anything looks distorted or uncanny, lower this first.

Depth Cutoff
What it is:
 protection control for faces and near objects.
Default: -1 (off)
What happens when you raise it (e.g. 0.4–0.7):
Very near pixels (faces, hands) become more anchored
Background still moves, foreground stays calmer
Reduces face warping risk
What happens if it’s too high:
Depth effect becomes weaker overall
👉 Use only if faces start to feel “pulled.”

Bars
Overlay
What it does:
Black bars always sit on top of everything
Nothing appears to cross them
What you’ll see:
Clean letterbox
Depth only visible inside the window

Breakout (Near Over Bars)
What it does:
Near parts of the image can remain visible inside the bar area
Far/background stays blacked out
What you’ll see:
Heads, shoulders, or arms appear to “break” into the bars
Classic / trailer-style depth illusion
👉 This is the mode you want for the cinematic “pop-out” look.

Breakout Cutoff

What it is:
Controls how near something must be to appear over the bars.
Lower value (e.g. 0.3):
More of the image breaks into the bars
Higher value (e.g. 0.6–0.7):
Only the closest parts break through (faces, hands)
Too low:
Can feel messy
Too high:
Almost nothing breaks through
👉 Sweet spot is usually 0.35–0.5.




Typical “general” setup
Preset: FaceSafe
Strength: 0.8 – 1.0
Bars: Breakout (Near Over Bars)
Breakout Cutoff: 0.4

nodes.title: PRESETS
widgets_values:
Presets:  If you select Default then you can overide the seetings with the sliders, If you select anything other than default then those settings are predeined.


DEFAULT (Manual Mode)
Uses whatever your UI sliders are set to, nothing overridden.

STRONG_POP | Effect | Very strong pop-out foreground, mild background |
ipd_norm = 0.12
depth_strength = 1.4
max_disp_norm = 0.12
fg_boost = 1.8
bg_boost = 0.9
focus_mode = "Median"

CINEMATIC | Effect | Natural depth, low strain |
ipd_norm = 0.05
depth_strength = 0.9
max_disp_norm = 0.06
fg_boost = 1.1
bg_boost = 1.1
focus_mode = "Median"

BACKGROUND_DEPTH | Effect | Foreground mostly flat, background has deep parallax |
ipd_norm = 0.06
depth_strength = 1.0
max_disp_norm = 0.10
fg_boost = 0.2
bg_boost = 2.2
focus_mode = "Median"

PORTRAIT | Effect | Minimal facial warping, depth behind the subject |
ipd_norm = 0.04
depth_strength = 0.7
max_disp_norm = 0.05
fg_boost = 0.9
bg_boost = 1.2
focus_mode = "Manual"
manual_focus = 0.70
 
FOCUS_LOCK (manual focal plane) | Effect | Strong pop-out only for objects near chosen plane |
ipd_norm = 0.06
depth_strength = 1.0
max_disp_norm = 0.10
fg_boost = 2.0
bg_boost = 1.0
focus_mode = "Manual"
manual_focus = 0.35

REVERSE_PARALLAX | Effect | Depth inverted—everything goes into the screen |
max_disp_norm = 0.10
fg_boost = 0.8
bg_boost = 1.6
invert_internal_depth = True
invert_external_depth = False

VR180_PREP (for equirect projection node afterwards) | Effect | Wide stereo suitable for hemisphere projection |
ipd_norm = 0.09
depth_strength = 1.3
max_disp_norm = 0.15
focus_mode = "Manual"
manual_focus = 0.55
invert_internal_depth = False

Here's some help:

As all humans and all images are different, you will have to work out a setting that is best for you. If you know VR then you will understand we dont have the same IPD and depending on what you want to 'pop' out of the image is subjective. Use the text_debug output to connect to the filename, so you know what settings you used on that image, so can make adjustments based on your preference.


ipd_norm is a scalar multiplier that represents how far apart the virtual cameras (left & right) are, relative to the image width. It does not mean real-world millimeters. It simulates the effect of changing the interpupillary distance (IPD) in a normalized coordinate system so it works across different image resolutions.Humans average ~63mm IPD—but we can't use actual mm, because the image isn’t in mm.

ipd_norm gives a relative virtual baseline like:
ipd_norm	Real-world analogy
0.01–0.03	macro photography, tiny baseline
0.04–0.07	normal human eye spacing-ish
0.08–0.12	exaggerated 3D, hyper stereo
0.15+	toy stereo, uncomfortable, breaks depth cues


depth_strength affects how much depth varies disparity.ipd_norm affects how much all disparity is scaled globally
In simple terms:
depth_strength controls how strong foreground vs background separation is.  ipd_norm controls how wide the stereo baseline is overall.



max_disp_norm sets the maximum allowed horizontal shift (disparity) between the left and right eye projections, expressed as a fraction of image width.  It acts as a safety clamp so that depth-based parallax doesn’t become extreme or uncomfortable
0.00–0.02	Almost no 3D
0.03–0.06	Natural stereo depth
0.07–0.12	Strong pop-out effects
>0.15	        Exaggerated / fake depth


focus_mode decides which depth value is treated as the "screen plane", meaning the depth level where there is zero stereo disparity (no left/right shift). Everything closer than that pops toward the viewer, everything farther sinks into the frame. It basically defines what part of the scene feels “at screen distance” rather than floating outward or inward.

focus_mode = "median" (automatic / default)
This calculates the median depth across the scene: focus = median(depth_map)
Meaning: Whatever depth most of the image sits at becomes the stable plane. Foreground objects pop out. Background sinks slightly. This works best when: Subject is centered, Depth map is clean, Scene isn't ultra-wide, Good default for portraits and normal indoor scenes.

focus_mode = "manual" (complete control)
Here you pick the plane using:  manual_focus (0.0 = far, 1.0 = near)
So if you want the subject to sit on the screen plane (no stereo shift): Set manual_focus to that subject’s depth.
If you want to push the whole scene back (3D theatrics):Use a far depth like 0.2.
If you want things to pop out aggressively: Use a deeper background focus and let subject be closer than focus

How to choose values
Goal	Mode	manual_focus suggestion
Natural portrait	median	N/A
Subject on the screen plane	manual	~0.6–0.75
Background on screen plane	manual	~0.2–0.3
Maximum pop-out	manual	~0.1
Make everything flat	manual	≈ depth of the whole scene


The node can take a depth map externally such as Depth Anything (which is better) but the node also has a depthmap within it, it is not as good as Depth Anything but it can offer subtlety of 3D

nodes.title: Preview Image (the more you see the more it will 'pop')

widgets_values: You dont have to use the node above, you can use the normal DepthAnything node. I just made this node so I could swap between different depth models rather than having loads of nodes everywhere, so packaged it in 1 node.

ARRGGHH ! What do all the settings do!   **********  SkyboxVR needs "_FULL_SBS" somewhere in the filename *******************
****************************************

Here's some help:

As all humans and all images are different, you will have to work out a setting that is best for you. If you know VR then you will understand we dont have the same IPD and depending on what you want to 'pop' out of the image is subjective. Use the text_debug output to connect to the filename, so you know what settings you used on that image, so can make adjustments based on your preference.

ipd_norm is a scalar multiplier that represents how far apart the virtual cameras (left & right) are, relative to the image width. It does not mean real-world millimeters. It simulates the effect of changing the interpupillary distance (IPD) in a normalized coordinate system so it works across different image resolutions.Humans average ~63mm IPD—but we can't use actual mm, because the image isn’t in mm.

ipd_norm gives a relative virtual baseline like:
ipd_norm	Real-world analogy
0.01–0.03	macro photography, tiny baseline
0.04–0.07	normal human eye spacing-ish
0.08–0.12	exaggerated 3D, hyper stereo
0.15+	toy stereo, uncomfortable, breaks depth cues

depth_strength affects how much depth varies disparity.ipd_norm affects how much all disparity is scaled globally
In simple terms:
depth_strength controls how strong foreground vs background separation is.  ipd_norm controls how wide the stereo baseline is overall.

max_disp_norm sets the maximum allowed horizontal shift (disparity) between the left and right eye projections, expressed as a fraction of image width.  It acts as a safety clamp so that depth-based parallax doesn’t become extreme or uncomfortable
0.00–0.02	Almost no 3D
0.03–0.06	Natural stereo depth
0.07–0.12	Strong pop-out effects
>0.15	        Exaggerated / fake depth

focus_mode decides which depth value is treated as the "screen plane", meaning the depth level where there is zero stereo disparity (no left/right shift). Everything closer than that pops toward the viewer, everything farther sinks into the frame. It basically defines what part of the scene feels “at screen distance” rather than floating outward or inward.

focus_mode = "median" (automatic / default)
This calculates the median depth across the scene: focus = median(depth_map)
Meaning: Whatever depth most of the image sits at becomes the stable plane. Foreground objects pop out. Background sinks slightly. This works best when: Subject is centered, Depth map is clean, Scene isn't ultra-wide, Good default for portraits and normal indoor scenes.

focus_mode = "manual" (complete control)
Here you pick the plane using:  manual_focus (0.0 = far, 1.0 = near)
So if you want the subject to sit on the screen plane (no stereo shift): Set manual_focus to that subject’s depth.
If you want to push the whole scene back (3D theatrics):Use a far depth like 0.2.
If you want things to pop out aggressively: Use a deeper background focus and let subject be closer than focus

How to choose values
Goal	Mode	manual_focus suggestion
Natural portrait	median	N/A
Subject on the screen plane	manual	~0.6–0.75
Background on screen plane	manual	~0.2–0.3
Maximum pop-out	manual	~0.1
Make everything flat	manual	≈ depth of the whole scene

The node can take a depth map externally such as Depth Anything (which is better) but the node also has a depthmap within it, it is not as good as Depth Anything but it can offer subtlety of 3D

737676624462095
Change Seed to random, this is just fixed to produce the image example

nodes.title: Image Concatenate (this merges left/right eye images) ** You may need to swap them based on your headset**

widgets_values: If you don't the frame number you want to start and end on, the node below will put the number of of each frame overlayed on top, which will help you discover the Start and end frames you want to select.
The node above is not required for the worflow, its there to demonstarte the nodes ability to capture specific frame numbers as an image or a batch of images.

nodes.title: TextOverlay Instructions
widgets_values:
Text overlay node, allows for text to be burnt into the image.
All the settings should be obvious.

From start - frame end
top_left, top_center, top_right
center_left, center, center_right
bottom_left, bottom_center, bottom_right

Or for position, you can use pixel offsets eg. x=120 y=800

Examples:
30-50 | top_center | Hello
70-100 | x=200 y=220 | you

Anaglyph_type: Select the glasses type you have.

Channel Balance (default = 1.0)
(Ghost reduction / eye comfort)

What it does
Scales the contribution of the non-dominant channels
Reduces retinal rivalry and color bleed
Example
1.0 = full cyan
0.7 = softer cyan → less ghosting
0.5 = comfort-biased


Depth Strength (default = 0)
(Horizontal pixel shift before encoding)
What it does
Applies a small pre-shift:
Left shifts left, Right shifts right
Increases or decreases perceived depth

Why it matters
Different content needs different disparity
Glasses + screen size dependent
Recommended range
-10 → +10 pixels (or similar)
0 = neutral
depth resolution must match the snallest dimension (width or height) of the image

nodes.title: Image Concatenate (this merges left/right eye images) ** You may need to swap them based on your headset**

widgets_values: The reason for the small batch size is purely down to VRAM. remember, the number of frames you use, is going to be souble due to 2 images needed in SBS, so although this says 7 (example you can change it), effectively it means 14 images will be processed as the end result per batch which are upscaled

nodes.title: Settings for YT
widgets_values:
How you add Google Spatial Media metadata to an MP4 (the only way YouTube reliably recognises 3D)

You do not do this with FFmpeg.
You do it with Google’s Spatial Media Metadata Injector.

groups.title: WAN to SBS VR - Low VRAM or Extra long video.2 to SBS
Ease In/Out Node with VFI built in
Bullet Time with VFI (normal both ends, slow down in the middle)
Pulfrich Effect to SBS (no VR Headset required)
Load Video to Anaglyph 3D (Anaglyph glasses needed)
